- Hey, what's up guys?
Welcome back to Binging with Babish
where this week we are taking a look
at the shortbread biscuits
from the disarmingly charming Fred Lasso.

Brant, Ted Lasso, that
was a real outtake folks,

I'm leaving it in there as a
sort of punishment to myself.
Anyway, let's start with a really,
very quick and easy shortbread.
Into a large bowl goes 225 grams
of softened unsalted butter,
100 grams granulated sugar,
and three grams of kosher salt.

We're beatin' all these
together into a paste
using a regular sized whisk,

and then we're adding
340 grams of plain flour.

Mixing together at first
with a rubber spatula,
and then once it becomes too crumbly,

utilizing our bare mitts until
the mixture is homogenous,
there are no more dry spots,

and we have a lovely crumbly
dough, an early indicator
that we have achieved a nice short pastry.
Then we are liberally lubricating

a quarter sheet with butter,
dropping in our dough,
and starting to press it down flat.
You don't wanna press it too much,

something that I'm
definitely doing right now.

but this is my first
batch, give me a break.

Oh no Andy, don't use
the, ah, you used it.
Anyway, once we packed that way too tight,
it's headed into a 150 degree Celsius oven

for a whopping one to
one and one half hours.

Then we're going to let
it cool for 10 minutes
before measuring and slicing.

I say measuring, because I have
a pretty pink pastry parcel,
just like Coach Lasso,
that I want them to be able to fit in.

Then once they are sliced,
it's time to let them rest

until completely cooled,
at least four hours

before retrieving them
with your very smallest,
and thinnest, offset spatula.

And as you can see, I
compressed them way too hard

and I strongly suspect
that they were under baked,
but they still had a lovely crumbly

short texture, and
beautiful buttery flavor.
So we're going to try again,

this time both adding
some secret ingredients,
and fixing my mistakes.
First up, toasted sugar.

A sugar whose virtues
are endlessly extolled
by the one and only Stella Parks.

Basically, we're just pouring
a whole bunch of sugar

into a large casserole,
and baking at 150 Celsius
for anywhere from two to three hours.

We're moving in tiny whisking,
every 15 to 20 minutes
until the sugar is a golden toasty brown.
Allow to cool completely before using.

Next step, some nutty
and toasty brown butter
where we cook and constantly swirl

some butter in a medium saute
pan over medium high heat
until the milk fat's separate and brown.

Likewise, let it cool
completely before using.
Now, in the bowl of the stand mixer,

we are combining 140
grams of unsalted butter,
55 grams of our brown butter,
140 grams of our toasted sugar,
and three grams of salt.
Creaming on high speed until creamed.

Give the sides of the
bowl a good scrape down,
and then in a separate bowl combine

275 grams of plain flour
and 55 grams of corn starch.
Tiny whisking to combine,
before dumping into the stand mixer.
Mix on low speed for one to two minutes
until a crumbly dough forms,
at which point it's time to incorporate
our final secret ingredient.

We're thoroughly buttering
our quarter sheet like usual,
and then coating evenly in Demerara sugar,
a coarse, crunchy, molassesy, sugar,

that's gonna give our
shortbread that crumbly look
that they have on the show.
This time, much more gently,

we are patting our dough
into the prepared sheet pan,

topping with a generous
layer of Demerara sugar,
so it's coating on all sides.
And baking, once again, at 150 Celsius

for anywhere from one
to one and a half hours.

This time making sure that it
emerges looking golden brown
and crisp around the edges.
Once again, waiting 10 minutes before
carving into our specified shapes,

allowing it to cool completely
at least four hours.

Retrieving our biscuits before
the most important part,
box assembly.

I have here a 150
millimeter by 115 millimeter

by 70 millimeter pastry box,
which should fit our biscuits

like whatever the British
equivalent of a glove is.

I know that they're a lot bigger
than the ones on the show,
but they have the same beautiful
golden brown, crumbly texture.

The kind that you can
tell is going to be sweet,

and short, and crunchy, and
nutty, just by looking at it.
And it is all of those things,
it is my new favorite shortbread.
There's only one more thing we need

to make it truly biscuits
with gloss, and that is tea.

AKA, Ted Lasso's garbage water,
but you know what they say?
One man's garbage water is another man's
treasure water.
